This is Superintendent of Schools, Steve Lemanski, with an important message for high school staff and students. I received a report late last evening that a family member of an Agawam High School student has flu-like symptoms and was reporting to his physician. Out of an abundance of caution, I am cancelling school for the high school today. I repeat, the cancellation is for the high school only.

I anticipate the high school will be back on schedule for next week. As you are aware, the Coronavirus is changing how we do business on a daily basis. I urge you all to take precautions to keep yourselves healthy.

I will keep you posted on the latest developments as information on the virus comes forth.

Thank you and have a good day.

Steve Lemanski

post_text: On Thursday, May 30th a historic event occurred at Agawam Junior High School, a weather balloon was launched into space. Students and faculty watched as the balloon slipped through the clouds into the upper levels of space. The balloon ascended to a height of 103,000 ft or 24 miles into the sky. After floating in space for 102 minutes, it finally landed in Norwell where the payload carrying the weather instruments and cameras was retrieved. Students will be spending the next several days graphing the data and watching the GoPro videos to see observe the marshmallow and radiation beads sent up with the balloon.

The Metalwork class at Agawam High School are proud to share pictures with you of some of their projects. One student assignment centered on evaluating technique and knowledge in using metal working tools, the MIG welder and the plasma torch. Students had to design a weather vane with some kind of plasma cut design for the top. They had to sketch, make a template and then cut the final design out of sheet metal. Then they welded together a post including a directional so that he vane could rotate freely.

One student this year took on a special project and created a fire ring. The student created the design on sheet metal and then cut it using the plasma cutter. He reinforced the ring and then created a handle with a center grill to cook food over the ring.

We hope you enjoy the pictures of these wonderful metalwork creations done by our Agawam High School students!

The Plastics - Additive Manufacturing class at Agawam High School did an interesting project. The students were split into two teams and had to work together to design the seven different pieces of a chess set using a theme of their choice: the king, queen, bishop, knight, rook, pawn and an actual square of the chess board. They did this using a 3D printer which created the chess pieces. The best design pieces were then replicated to create the entire Chess board. These pictures show the assembly process and the resulting chess board.

The students were split into two teams and had to work together to design the seven different pieces of a chess set using a theme of their choice: the king, queen, bishop, knight, rook, pawn and an actual square of the chess board. They did this using a 3D printer which created the chess pieces. The best design pieces were then replicated to create the entire Chess board. These pictures show the assembly process and the resulting chess board.

post_text: Think Virtual Reality is a thing of the future? Think again. It is now possible to take a virtual tour of the Seven Wonders of the World or visit Ancient Egypt…even explore a coal mine… all from your Agawam Public Schools’ classroom. Students use these special devices that look like binoculars but are very hi-tech to take the virtual tours. These devices are linked to an iPad through an App that creates the projection of the virtual lesson. Think of the possibilities? A teacher can be reading the Diary of Anne Frank with their students and then transport the students to a virtual look at her life and time. Lessons are available for most subjects and grade levels. A class can tour an art museum or explore the circulatory system. It is up to the teacher. Teachers can sign up to use these devices through the IT Helpdesk. The possibilities are VIRTUALLY endless.

post_text: The Agawam Public Schools held Inclusive Schools Week district-wide on December 3rd through December 7th. Schools had a variety of school and classroom activities centered on inclusive practices. Featured in this post is Principal Nicholas Bernier reading to students at Robinson Park School. The book he was reading was called "The Sandwich Swap." It was about two children who get into a conflict because they don't understand parts of each other's' cultures, in this case, food. Ultimately, they end up trying each other's sandwiches, and find that they really enjoy them. The lesson the book teaches is that no matter how different people might be from one another, they can still get along and be friends if they work to understand each other. This fits in perfectly with what Inclusive Schools Week is celebrating.
